articles.abstract: Job creation all but stalled in February, surprising Wall Street forecasters and giving Democrats economic ammunition to use against Pres Bush as he begins his re-election campaign; Labor Dept reports that economy added just 21,000 jobs, down sharply from Jan's increase and far below gains that were common in 1980's and 1990's; unemployment rate held steady at 5.6 percent, mostly because many people have stopped looking for work since late last year, removing them from government's official count of jobless; economists say that at no other point since World War II has economy grown for such long period without adding jobs at healthy pace; graphs (M)

articles.abstract: Southwest Airlines, which prospered offering no-frills efficiency, cheap seats and jokes from flight attendants, is facing stiffer competition from low-fare rivals that offer more frills and traditional airlines that are cutting fares and offering premiums; weighs adding frills like in-flight entertainment systems and expanding its fleet; says its secret weapon remains its affable employees; plans to add service to Philadelphia, where US Airways, scrambling for its financial life, has vowed to fight back; market share table; drawing; photos (M)

articles.headline: ABC Under Disney: Kingdom, Yes. Magic, No.; Micromanagement Leads To Missed Opportunities
articles.snippet: ''The Apprentice,'' the new NBC reality program celebrating the corporate wisdom of Donald J. Trump, is a ''total game changer,'' in the words of Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment. Averaging 20 million viewers a week and pulling in m...
articles.abstract: ''The Apprentice,'' the new NBC reality program celebrating the corporate wisdom of Donald J. Trump, is a ''total game changer,'' in the words of Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment. Averaging 20 million viewers a week and pulling in more high-income viewers than any other series, it has saved NBC's once-invincible Thursday night lineup, turned around its season and added millions in profit -- with the promise of more millions to come.     But ''The Apprentice'' is also a show that could have belonged to ABC, the network that needs a big hit more desperately than any other. Mark Burnett, who after his success with ''Survivor'' and now ''The Apprentice'' is the most sought after producer of reality shows, first offered his new series to ABC. But negotiations there quickly turned into an effort to force down the price, and he turned to NBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: ''The Apprentice,'' the new NBC reality program celebrating the corporate wisdom of Donald J.
